      Crash Count for Queens
      Crashes: Collisions involving cars, bikes, and pedestrians. 89,973
      All Injuries: Any injury from a reported crash. 52,101
      Moderate: Broken bones, concussions, and other serious injuries. 9,685
      Serious: Life-altering injuries: amputations, paralysis, severe trauma. 566
      Deaths: Lives lost to traffic violence. 288
      Data from Jan 1, 2022 to Sep 19, 2025

      About these crash totals

      Counts come from NYC police crash reports (NYC Open Data). We sum all crashes, injuries, and deaths for this area across the selected time window shown on the card. Injury severity follows the official definitions in the NYPD dataset.

      • Crashes: number of police‑reported collisions (all road users).
      • All injuries: total injured people in those crashes.
      • Moderate / Serious: subcategories reported by officers (e.g., broken bones vs. life‑threatening trauma).
      • Deaths: people who died due to a crash.

      Notes: Police reports can be corrected after initial publication. Minor incidents without a police report are not included.

      Who’s Injuring and Killing Pedestrians in Queens?

      About this chart

      We group pedestrian injuries and deaths by the vehicle type that struck them (as recorded in police reports). Use the dropdown to view totals, serious injuries, or deaths.

      • Trucks/Buses, SUVs/Cars, Mopeds, and Bikes reflect the reporting categories in the crash dataset.
      • Counts include people on foot only; crashes with no injured pedestrians are not shown here.

      Notes: Police classification can change during investigations. Small categories may have year-to-year variance.

      Preventable Speeding in Queens School Zones

      (since 2022)
      1,635,626 6+
      652,729 16+

      About these numbers

      These totals count vehicles with at least the shown number of camera‑issued speeding violations (school‑zone speed cameras) in any rolling 12‑month window in this district. Totals are summed from 2022 to the present for this geography.

      • ≥ 6 (6+): advocates’ standard for repeat speeding offenders who should face escalating consequences.
      • ≥ 16 (16+): threshold in the current edited bill awaiting State Senate action.

      About this list

      This ranks vehicles by the number of NYC school‑zone speed‑camera violations they received in the last 12 months anywhere in the city. The smaller note shows how many times the same plate was caught in this area in the last 90 days.

      Camera violations are issued by NYC DOT’s program. Counts reflect issued tickets and may omit dismissed or pending cases. Plate text is shown verbatim as recorded.

      Queens dawn, a man down on the Belt Parkway

      Queens: Jan 1, 2022 - Sep 21, 2025

      Just before 6 AM on Sep 12, 2025, a person walking on the Belt Parkway in Queens was killed by drivers heading west. Police recorded three drivers; two in sedans and one in an SUV. NYC Open Data

      This Week

      • On Aug 31 at 30 St and 39 Ave, the driver of an SUV turned right and hit a 38-year-old woman in a marked crosswalk; police recorded failure to yield by the driver. NYC Open Data
      • On Aug 23, a driver in a sedan going west hit a 38-year-old man who was outside an intersection; police recorded driver distraction. NYC Open Data

      The count does not stop

      Since 2022, 288 people have been killed in crashes in Queens, with 52,064 injured and 566 listed as seriously hurt. NYC Open Data

      This year, 56 people are dead in Queens crashes, compared with 49 at this point last year. Serious injuries are 148, up from 127. NYC Open Data

      Who bears the blows

      Since 2022, drivers in SUVs have killed 50 people walking in Queens; sedan drivers have killed 32; truck drivers 16; bus drivers 4. These are only pedestrians. NYC Open Data

      The repeat offense problem

      Speed is a habit that repeats until it breaks. This year, New York City’s school‑zone cameras have already issued 161,512 tickets that would have been blocked under a proposed device rule for the worst repeat speeders; 375,923 since 2022. These are tickets after a vehicle crossed a habitual‑speeder threshold, the ones this bill aims to prevent. [Context: Speeding Preventables]

      A tool exists. The Stop Super Speeders Act (S4045C/A2299C) would require drivers who pile up 11 DMV points in 18 months or 16 camera tickets in a year to use intelligent speed assistance that keeps them within 5 MPH of the limit. Take Action

      Who must answer here

      Queens is represented here by Council Member Vickie Paladino, Assembly Member Stacey Pheffer Amato, and State Senator James Sanders. The record above is their district’s burden to carry. The bills and tools exist; the deaths continue. NYC Open Data

      Slow the cars, save a life

      Lower the default speed. Stop the super speeders. These are concrete steps the city and state can take now. Start here: Take Action.

      Frequently Asked Questions

      ▸ How were these numbers calculated?
      We used NYC Open Data’s Motor Vehicle Collisions datasets: Crashes (h9gi-nx95), Person (f55k-p6yu), and Vehicles (bm4k-52h4). We filtered for crashes in Queens between 2022-01-01 and 2025-09-21, then counted deaths, injuries, serious injuries, and recent incidents. Pedestrian-by-vehicle-type figures come from the Person dataset where the person type is Pedestrian. Data were accessed Sep 21, 2025. You can run a filtered query for Queens and this date window in the Crashes dataset here.
      ▸ What is CrashCount?
      We’re a tool for helping hold local politicians and other actors accountable for their failure to protect you when you’re walking or cycling in NYC. We update our site constantly to provide you with up to date information on what’s happening in your neighborhood.
      ▸ Why focus on the Belt Parkway case?
      It is the most recent fatal crash in Queens within the coverage window and involves a person walking. The crash record shows three drivers going west; one in an SUV and two in sedans. Source: NYC Open Data Crashes dataset.
      ▸ How many people have been killed in Queens traffic since 2022?
      According to our filtered counts from NYC Open Data, 288 people have been killed in crashes in Queens between 2022-01-01 and 2025-09-21. See the filtered query link above.
      ▸ What can stop repeat speeders?
      Under the proposed Stop Super Speeders Act (S4045C/A2299C), drivers who rack up 11 DMV points in 18 months or 16 camera tickets in a year would have to use intelligent speed assistance to prevent speeding. Learn more and contact your officials on our Take Action page.

      SUV Driver Falls Asleep, Bus Crash Injures Six
      ▸

      Jun 29 - A sleeping SUV driver slammed into a bus on 147 Ave. Six people hurt. Faces bloodied, necks wrenched, bodies battered. The road stayed quiet. Metal and flesh took the blow.

      An SUV struck a bus on 147 Ave in Queens. Six people were injured, including drivers and passengers. According to the police report, the crash was caused by the driver falling asleep and losing consciousness. Injuries ranged from severe bleeding to whiplash and chest trauma. The police report lists 'Fell Asleep' and 'Lost Consciousness' as contributing factors. No mention of helmet or signal use as a cause. The impact left bodies bruised and shaken, exposing the danger when drivers lose control.

      ▸

      Jun 29 - A moped and sedan collided on Sutphin Blvd. Two riders were ejected, suffering head injuries. Police cite traffic control ignored and alcohol. The street ran red. Metal met flesh. Blood on the pavement.

According to the police report, 'Traffic Control Disregarded' and 'Alcohol Involvement' contributed to the crash. The moped passenger had severe bleeding. The moped driver and passenger were not using safety equipment. The sedan driver was licensed and uninjured. The report lists driver errors but does not blame those hurt.
